subject: Re: [junit] Categories in JUnit4?
msgSnippet: ... I find that if I really need to run all performance tests, or all integration tests, or all database tests, then I /really/ need to run /all/ the tests, so
messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 11/25/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
> >
> > The bottom line: if the tests are really /that/ different, then we
> > should emphasize the difference by placing the tests in different
> > locations, rather that merely annotating them.
>
> The problem with this approach is that it becomes impossible to put a test
> in more than one category, and I find that I need to do that very
> frequently.
>
> For example, a test could be "performance", "integration" and "database" at
> the same time.

I find that if I really need to run all performance tests, or all
integration tests, or all database tests, then I /really/ need to run
/all/ the tests, so I simply run them all.

> Groups also allow you to categorize your test methods even further: "slow"
> vs. "fast" for example, which is a good example of a crosscutting category.

This is /really/ how I typically split them, anyway.

> Finally, the physical location and the various names of my Java tests
> (package, class, method name) should be completely orthogonal to what groups
> they belong to. If I want to run only the database tests, all I want to
> know is "database" and not "com.beust.database.test1", "
> com.beust.database.account", etc...

Why do you have so many database tests? An application should be able to
get away with a dozen or so at the most. :) [I'm just having fun--I
don't really want to get into that discussion. Hold your cards and letters.]
